title: Thoughts on the new scaling laws for large language models

last_post.content:
DeepMind's paper refutes this last claim, and finds that both are equally useful.
The differences between DeepMind & OpenAI's papers matter in terms of forecasting how big LLMs need to get. They arrived at these different conclusions because DeepMind did more learning rate tuning. This blog post https://severelytheoretical.wordpress.com/2022/07/18/thoughts-on-the-new-scaling-laws-for-large-language-models/ hypothesizes that DeepMind's paper might also be not doing enough hyperparameter tuning, and the scaling law may be less severe, perhaps not even a power law.
3/3

title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Taking a closer look at this paper, I really dislike it.

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

It's clear that newer papers *must* have a lower “disruption” score than older ones under a null model — they even confirm this in the supplemental material with a randomization test. It's an artifact of their definition.

When comparing with the null model they compute only the z-score, getting values at most 4 or so. It's also besides the point — as usual, small meaningless deviations from the null model can be statistically “significant.” Effect size ≠ statistical significance.

Finally, according to their definition, review papers would be “disruptive” because they funnel a bunch of citations. And a paper that does not cite anyone but is universally cited would not be “disruptive”. 🤷

@networkscience
@academicchatter
#networkscience #networks

title: OOM on large monorepo project · Issue #1606 · TypeStrong/typedoc

last_post.content:
Typedoc is the de-facto standard doc generator for #TypeScript, but sadly doesn't really support monorepos. In practice it launches N instances of the TS compiler at once, then quickly runs out of memory... N is number of packages in the repo, in my case N=176 (w/ 3300+ source files). So to improve the #ThingUmbrella docs and provide better x-referencing & discoverability and other useful additions, I started working on a new experimental doc gen, still early days, but already v.promising. Really wonder how owners of other large TS projects are dealing with this, other than allocating >200GB(!) of RAM... 🤯

https://github.com/TypeStrong/typedoc/issues/1606#issuecomment-1353688993
Reverse order dependent origination can dismantle anything. Ending suffering is only one usage https://clerestory.netlify.app/do

title: Equity, Diversity and Inclusion: A guide for writing anti-racist tenure and promotion letters

last_post.content:
Senior faculty are incredibly powerful. In a two-page tenure letter, they can make or break a career. This power has an outsized impact on scholars with marginalized identities, such as Black academics, who are promoted with tenure at lower rates than their white colleagues.

Are you a senior faculty? Do you want to align your letters with your anti-racist values? A group of us, educated at #A4BL to disrupt anti-Black racism in academia, suggest practical steps how:

https://elifesciences.org/articles/79892

All who agree to behave decently are welcome. I turned governance over to the community more than a decade ago. If you are too rude, a small volunteer committee, who have the backing of all of us, will ask you to behave better or leave.

http://brainstormscommunity.org

(4/4)

I wrote about these experiences in online governance: http://rheingold.com/texts/OnlineGovernance.pdf

Brainstorms grew to an active community of around 500. We had meetups of a couple dozen people in San Francisco, Memphis, and Amsterdam. We contributed and distributed more than $10K in mutual aid. Like any community, we had our issues.

Then social media came along, and instead of message boards where overlapping populations talked about science and sex,

title: The Work of Martin Ravallion: A Round-up of Influential Research from an Exceptional Poverty Economist

last_post.content:
The year 2022 ended on a sad note with the passing of Martin Ravallion, one of the most influential economists working to measure (and reduce) poverty around.

If you’re just learning of Ravallion’s work, here’s a micro-summary of each of his 15 most cited (per year since publication) articles.

https://www.cgdev.org/blog/work-martin-ravallion-round-influential-research-exceptional-poverty-economist

Rest in peace, Professor Ravallion. My gratitude goes out to you for your leadership and your research.

Remembering Martin Ravallion (who sadly died on December 24): Berk Ozler and I offer some reflections on his work, how he helped both of us join the World Bank, why him not hiring me in his unit may have been the best gift he ever gave me, his surprising early career switch, and more . https://blogs.worldbank.org/impactevaluations/remembering-martin-ravallion

title: Make autosuggest for mentions return followed accounts first by dariusk · Pull Request #22956 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
Made a Mastodon pull request.

In v4, there is an issue on servers that don't have elasticsearch: when a user types @ in the compose box and starts to type a name, the results they get are ordered by a popularity ranking algorithm. This is fine if you were only searching accounts you don't follow, but to me it makes more sense to FIRST return matches for accounts you DO follow as a suggestion, and then return popular accounts that you don't follow

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/22956

What is this demonstrating, utility wise?

The fact that I can use a #SmartAgent like #gptChat to generate machine-computable structured data for upload to a knowledgebase (or #KnowledgeGraph).

Naturally, I can query said Knowledge Graph declaratively using #SQL, #SPARQL, or #GraphQL where query solutions also manifest in easy-to-reuse form e.g., #JSON, #CSV, etc..

SPARQL Example.
https://linkeddata.uriburner.com/sparql?query=%23%20DEFINE%20get%3Asoft%20%22soft%22%20%0ASELECT%20(SAMPLE(%3Fs)%20AS%20%3FEntityID)%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20(COUNT(*)%20AS%20%3Fcount)%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20(%3Fo%20AS%20%3FEntityTypeID)%20%0AFROM%20%3Curn%3Akidehen%3Agpt%3Asemweb%3Ademos%3E%20%0AWHERE%20%7B%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%3Fs%20a%20%3Fo%20.%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20FILTER%20(CONTAINS(STR(%3Fo)%2C%27schema%27))%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%7D%20%0AGROUP%20BY%20%3Fo%20%0AORDER%20BY%20DESC%20(%3Fcount)%20%0ALIMIT%2050%20%0A%0A%0A%0A&format=text%2Fx-html%2Btr

We are now in the Smart Agent stage re notion of a #SemanticWeb!

I'd like #Discord to help fund independently built #OpenSource projects by auto-unlocking server features instead of asking developers to spend personal $ to fund servers. Rationale and suggestions below :undefined:

1️⃣ Giving Back - Discord gives *thousands* a month to certain established projects that align with their tech stack's needs. 💡Unlocking the Level 1, 2, or 3 tiers for verified #OSS projects (maybe via a simple Google form?) seems to align with their values!

2️⃣ Advertising - Discord is often promoted at the top of most READMEs in a badge. Many companies, including Discord, pay to get a spot on an OSS project's README. 💡 Discord could proudly promote their sponsorship of these OSS projects in the Discord Client UI.

3️⃣ Help Redistribute $ to the Project - Many devs just wanna support the projects they love. Many OSS maintainers would prefer the $ go to supporting the maintenance of the project itself instead of the chat. 💡 Could we replace the "boost" button w/ a sponsorship link?

Discord's Open Collective contributions: https://opencollective.com/discordapp#category-BUDGET

#introduction

Hello I am Winter, or Autumn, or if you really want, Hussar. I'm a worldbuilder who enjoys video gaming, often I especially love exploring and vibing in them. I also occationally stream my map making at https://www.picarto.tv/TheWinterKiln

title: Songs that use Chromatic Mediant chords

last_post.content:
I'm not good enough to figure this out myself. I learned it from Dave Bennett's excellent video on chromatic mediants, which is full of examples:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_8D1F-wIqI

But what's a chromatic mediant? 🤔

'Mediant' just means 'third'. In a chromatic mediant we have two chords, ideally both major triads or both minor triads, that differ by a third and share a note. But what makes it 'chromatic' is that one of these triads is not in the same scale!

(2/n)

There are two pieces of news in this one:

https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-politics-controls-zuckerberg-meta-11672929976?mod=tech_lead_pos2
 
1.     In late 2021, with zero fanfare, Facebook began changing newsfeed worldwide to exclude comments and reshares in how it promotes politics, societal and health-related content.

2.     This wasn’t enough for FB’s leadership and board. Late in 2021, they asked Facebook to move forward with zero-weighting ALL civic content in newsfeed. Facebook wanted out of politics.

title: Believing in Credibility Measures: Reviewing Credibility Measures in Media Research From 1951 to 2018 | Hanimann | International Journal of Communication

last_post.content:
12 years ago @leahellmueller and I came up with the idea, 11 years ago we presented a prelimiary version at a conference, and now we finally have a journal paper (led by Anina Hanimann and Andri Heiman)! We present an analysis of N=259 (!) measures of media, message, and source #credibility, used over half a decade in published research, and give recommendations for how to operationalize credibility in today's media environment.
https://ijoc.org/index.php/ijoc/article/view/18815/3992 @communicationscholars #commodon

What gives Depeche Mode's song Enjoy the Silence that creepy feel?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_G0G1OjM5h0

I just learned one reason: a 'harmonic mediant'. Check out the part at 0:28 where Dave Gahan sings

Words like violence
Break the silence

The first line uses the notes 1 3♭ 5, which form a minor triad. The second uses 3♭ 5♭ 7♭, another minor triad. But while the first chord uses only notes in the minor scale, the second uses one note, 5♭, which is not in that scale!

Creepy!

(1/n)

The American Economic Association’s Committee on the Status of Women in the Economic Profession (CSWEP) and the Social Science Research Council (SSRC) invite proposals to evaluate cost-effective and scalable interventions designed to increase the presence and success of women throughout the economics discipline.

https://www.ssrc.org/programs/cswep-women-in-economics-research-consortium/

Submissions close August 31, 2023. #EconResearch #Funding

title: Twitter Hit With $228.9m Copyright Infringement / Repeat Infringer Lawsuit

last_post.content:
#Twitter may lose its #SafeHarbor protection because it's not responding to #takedown notices for repeat #copyright infringers.
https://torrentfreak.com/twitter-hit-with-228-9m-copyright-infringement-repeat-infringer-lawsuit-230104/

The article doesn't say so, but it seems that Twitter isn't responding to the takedown notices as US law requires ("expeditiously") because of the #Musk layoffs.

This is big. #SocialMedia platforms cannot operate in the US without a safe harbor from copyright lawsuits. It's as if Musk sawed off the wings of his plane to save weight.

title: What We Know About U.S.-Backed Zero Units in Afghanistan

last_post.content:
What We Know About U.S.-Backed Zero Units in Afghanistan
---
Just a few items, via @ProPublica --

•At least 452 civilians were killed in 107 raids

•A troubling number of raids appear to have relied on faulty CIA intelligence

•Former Afghan intel agency head acknowledged units were getting it wrong at times and killing civilians

•Afghan soldiers were often joined on raids by US special operations soldiers working with CIA

https://www.propublica.org/article/afghanistan-night-raids-zero-units-investigation-takeaways?utm_medium=social&utm_source=mastodon&utm_campaign=mastodon-post

For anyone who has ever correlated two variables (all of us), there is a fantastic paper on how to express a correlation as a probability: https://doi.org/10.5964/ps.7467
It explains why "This correlation means that someone high in x is also high in y" is almost always incorrect, and how uninformative medium values are. Comes with an #Rstats package.
(Also highly recommend for those of you in #scicomm )

Die Buddha-Statuen von Bamiyan wurden im 6. Jh. n. Chr. von buddhistischen Mönchen aus dem Fels gehauen.
Im März 2001 begannen die Taliban die Statuen restlos zu zerstören. Damit wollten sie ein Zeichen gegen Kultur & Toleranz setzen.

Mehr Infos unter: https://zerstoertes-kulturgut.github.io/Kulturst%C3%A4ttenNachL%C3%A4ndern/Afghanistan/Buddha-Statuen-Bamiyan.html
